channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Ancient DNA reveals first known case of sex-development disorder
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00101-z

Researchers identified six ancient humans with chromosomal conditions, including the earliest case of Turner syndrome.
item.dc:title: Ancient DNA reveals first known case of sex-development disorder
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: Earth boiled in 2023 — will it happen again in 2024?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00074-z

With last year now officially the hottest on record, climate researchers look ahead with trepidation.
item.dc:title: Earth boiled in 2023 — will it happen again in 2024?
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Google AI has better bedside manner than human doctors — and makes better diagnoses
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00099-4

Researchers say their artificial-intelligence system could help to democratize medicine.
item.dc:title: Google AI has better bedside manner than human doctors — and makes better diagnoses
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: ‘Set it and forget it’: automated lab uses AI and robotics to improve proteins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00093-w

A self-driving lab system spent half a year engineering enzymes to work at higher temperatures.
item.dc:title: ‘Set it and forget it’: automated lab uses AI and robotics to improve proteins
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: The Higgs boson is caught in a singular transformation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00006-x

Detectors at the Large Hadron Collider spot the famed particle decaying into a photon and a ‘Z boson’.
item.dc:title: The Higgs boson is caught in a singular transformation

item.title: Medical AI falters when assessing patients it hasn’t seen
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00094-9

Physicians rely on algorithms for personalized medicine — but an analysis of schizophrenia trials shows the tools fail to adapt to new data sets.
item.dc:title: Medical AI falters when assessing patients it hasn’t seen
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Oceans break heat records five years in a row
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00081-0

The heat stored in the world’s oceans increased by the greatest margin ever in 2023.
item.dc:title: Oceans break heat records five years in a row
item.dc:creator: Xiaoying You

item.title: Yaws could soon be eradicated — 70 years behind schedule
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00013-y

Researchers are cautiously optimistic that the neglected tropical disease could be gone by 2030, but new barriers — including antibiotic resistance and primate reservoirs — might stand in the way.
item.dc:title: Yaws could soon be eradicated — 70 years behind schedule
item.dc:creator: Sam Jones

item.title: This is the oldest fossilized reptile skin ever found — it pre-dates the dinosaurs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00032-9

Permian-period petroleum helped to preserve minute scraps of pebbly hide that probably belonged to a lizard-like creature.
item.dc:title: This is the oldest fossilized reptile skin ever found — it pre-dates the dinosaurs
item.dc:creator: Emma Marris

item.title: What counts as plagiarism? Harvard president’s resignation sparks debate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00035-6

Allegations against Claudine Gay have left researchers arguing over academic standards and practices.
item.dc:title: What counts as plagiarism? Harvard president’s resignation sparks debate
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: Urban youth most isolated in largest cities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04083-2

GPS data reveal that young people encounter fewer individuals from diverse groups than do adults. The isolation of young people is exacerbated in larger cities, and for those living in poverty.
item.dc:title: Urban youth most isolated in largest cities
item.dc:creator: Victor Couture

item.title: Daily briefing: Norway is first to approve controversial seabed mining
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00097-6

Norwegian scientists say that the government ignored their advice when they approved mining that could irreversibly damage biodiversity and ecosystems. Plus, many traits of modern Europeans have roots in ancient migrations and insects use clever physics to fling pee.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Norway is first to approve controversial seabed mining
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Sticky gels designed for tissue-healing therapies and diagnostics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03996-2

Materials that adhere tightly to human tissues can promote healing and boost the sensitivity of biomedical diagnostic devices. An ‘evolving’ gel has been made that synergizes two strategies for forming interfaces with tissue.
item.dc:title: Sticky gels designed for tissue-healing therapies and diagnostics
item.dc:creator: Sophia J. Bailey
Eric A. Appel

item.title: Author Correction: A new antibiotic traps lipopolysaccharide in its intermembrane transporter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07035-6

Author Correction: A new antibiotic traps lipopolysaccharide in its intermembrane transporter
item.dc:title: Author Correction: A new antibiotic traps lipopolysaccharide in its intermembrane transporter

item.title: Author Correction: Conserved and divergent gene regulatory programs of the mammalian neocortex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-07013-4

Author Correction: Conserved and divergent gene regulatory programs of the mammalian neocortex
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Conserved and divergent gene regulatory programs of the mammalian neocortex

item.title: The science stories you missed over the holiday period
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00085-w

We highlight some of the Nature Briefing’s stories from the end of 2023, including a polar bear fur-inspired sweater, efforts to open OSIRIS-REx’s sample canister, and a dinosaur’s last dinner.
item.dc:title: The science stories you missed over the holiday period
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Noah Baker
Flora Graham

item.title: Catalytic asymmetric cationic shifts of aliphatic hydrocarbons
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06826-7

We describe an imidodiphosphorimidate-catalysed asymmetric Wagner–Meerwein shift of aliphatic alkenyl cycloalkanes to cycloalkenes with excellent regio- and enantioselectivity.
item.dc:title: Catalytic asymmetric cationic shifts of aliphatic hydrocarbons
item.dc:creator: Vijay N. Wakchaure
William DeSnoo
Croix J. Laconsay
Markus Leutzsch
Nobuya Tsuji
Dean J. Tantillo
Benjamin List

item.title: Giant magnetocaloric effect in spin supersolid candidate Na<sub>2</sub>BaCo(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06885-w

Evidence for a quantum magnetic analogue of a supersolid appears in a recently synthesized antiferromagnet showing a strong magnetocaloric effect of the spin supersolid phase with potential for applications in sub-kelvin refrigeration.
item.dc:title: Giant magnetocaloric effect in spin supersolid candidate Na<sub>2</sub>BaCo(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>

item.title: Adding α,α-disubstituted and β-linked monomers to the genetic code of an organism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06897-6

tRNA display enables the direct selection of orthogonal aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases that acylate orthogonal tRNAs with non-canonical monomers, enabling in vivo synthesis of proteins that include these monomers and expanding the repertoire of the genetic code.
item.dc:title: Adding α,α-disubstituted and β-linked monomers to the genetic code of an organism
item.dc:creator: Daniel L. Dunkelmann
Carlos Piedrafita
Alexandre Dickson
Kim C. Liu
Thomas S. Elliott
Marc Fiedler
Dom Bellini
Andrew Zhou
Daniele Cervettini
Jason W. Chin

item.title: Capturing the generation and structural transformations of molecular ions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06909-5

The use of mega-electronvolt ultrafast electron diffraction combined with resonance-enhanced multiphoton ionization yields data that can reveal the formation and subsequent structural relaxation of a molecular ion on an ultrafast timescale.
item.dc:title: Capturing the generation and structural transformations of molecular ions
item.dc:creator: Jun Heo
Doyeong Kim

Hyotcherl Ihee

item.title: 100 ancient genomes show repeated population turnovers in Neolithic Denmark
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06862-3

Integrated data, including 100 human genomes from the Mesolithic, Neolithic and Early Bronze Age periods show that two major population turnovers occurred over just 1,000 years in Neolithic Denmark, resulting in dramatic changes in the genes, diet and physical appearance of the local people, as well as the landscape in which they lived.
item.dc:title: 100 ancient genomes show repeated population turnovers in Neolithic Denmark

item.title: A lethal mitonuclear incompatibility in complex I of natural hybrids
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06895-8

Analysis of naturally hybridizing swordtail fish species reveals a mitonuclear genetic incompatibility among three genes that encode components of mitochondrial respiratory complex I, providing insights into the emergence of hybrid incompatibilities and reproductive barriers.
item.dc:title: A lethal mitonuclear incompatibility in complex I of natural hybrids
item.dc:creator: Benjamin M. Moran

item.title: The CRISPR effector Cam1 mediates membrane depolarization for phage defence
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06902-y

The prokaryotic non-enzymatic effector protein Cam1 mediates CRISPR immunity by binding tetra-adenylate second messengers and forming a pore in the membrane that induces membrane depolarization and growth arrest.
item.dc:title: The CRISPR effector Cam1 mediates membrane depolarization for phage defence
item.dc:creator: Christian F. Baca
You Yu
Jakob T. Rostøl
Puja Majumder
Dinshaw J. Patel
Luciano A. Marraffini

item.title: A 12.4-day periodicity in a close binary system after a supernova
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06787-x

A stripped-envelope supernova, SN 2022jli, shows 12.4-day periodic undulations during the declining light curve, and narrow Hα emission is detected in late-time spectra with concordant periodic velocity shifts.
item.dc:title: A 12.4-day periodicity in a close binary system after a supernova
item.dc:creator: Ping Chen

item.title: Encoding a magic state with beyond break-even fidelity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06846-3

A scheme to prepare a magic state, an important ingredient for quantum computers, on a superconducting qubit array using error correction is proposed that produces better magic states than those that can be prepared using the individual qubits of the device.
item.dc:title: Encoding a magic state with beyond break-even fidelity
item.dc:creator: Riddhi S. Gupta
Neereja Sundaresan
Thomas Alexander

Andrew W. Cross

Benjamin J. Brown

item.title: Population genomics of post-glacial western Eurasia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06865-0

An analysis involving the shotgun sequencing of more than 300 ancient genomes from Eurasia reveals a deep east–west genetic divide from the Black Sea to the Baltic, and provides insight into the distinct effects of the Neolithic transition on either side of this boundary.
item.dc:title: Population genomics of post-glacial western Eurasia

item.title: Evidence of human influence on Northern Hemisphere snow loss
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06794-y

Snowpack reconstructions for major river basins in the Northern Hemisphere reveal that the snowpack has declined in almost half of the basins, with roughly one-third of the declines attributable to human-induced warming.
item.dc:title: Evidence of human influence on Northern Hemisphere snow loss
item.dc:creator: Alexander R. Gottlieb
Justin S. Mankin

item.title: The demise of the giant ape Gigantopithecus blacki
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06900-0

A multiproxy record of Gigantopithecus blacki provides insights into the ecological context of this species, which became extinct around 250,000 years ago, when increased seasonality led to a change in forest cover.
item.dc:title: The demise of the giant ape Gigantopithecus blacki
item.dc:creator: Yingqi Zhang

item.title: Three-dimensional integration of two-dimensional field-effect transistors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06860-5

Monolithic three-dimensional integration of two-dimensional field-effect transistors enables improved integration density and multifunctionality to realize ‘More Moore’ and ‘More than Moore’ technologies.
item.dc:title: Three-dimensional integration of two-dimensional field-effect transistors
item.dc:creator: Darsith Jayachandran

Yang Yang
Saptarshi Das

item.title: The selection landscape and genetic legacy of ancient Eurasians
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06705-1

Analyses of imputed ancient genomes and of samples from the UK Biobank indicate that ancient selection and migration were large contributors to the distribution of phenotypic diversity in present-day Europeans.
item.dc:title: The selection landscape and genetic legacy of ancient Eurasians

item.title: MRE11 liberates cGAS from nucleosome sequestration during tumorigenesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06889-6

The double-strand break sensor MRE11 is identified as a pivotal mediator of cGAS activation in response to multiple types of DNA damage.
item.dc:title: MRE11 liberates cGAS from nucleosome sequestration during tumorigenesis

item.title: Consistent patterns of common species across tropical tree communities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06820-z

Inventory data from more than 1 million trees across African, Amazonian and Southeast Asian tropical forests suggests that, despite their high diversity, just 1,053 species, representing a consistent ~2.2% of tropical tree species in each region, constitute half of Earth’s 800 billion tropical trees.
item.dc:title: Consistent patterns of common species across tropical tree communities

item.title: Operando probing of the surface chemistry during the Haber–Bosch process
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06844-5

Using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, the surface composition of iron and ruthenium catalysts during ammonia synthesis at pressures up to 1 bar and temperatures as high as 723 K can be revealed.
item.dc:title: Operando probing of the surface chemistry during the Haber–Bosch process
item.dc:creator: Christopher M. Goodwin
Patrick Lömker
David Degerman
Bernadette Davies
Mikhail Shipilin
Fernando Garcia-Martinez
Sergey Koroidov
Jette Katja Mathiesen
Raffael Rameshan
Gabriel L. S. Rodrigues
Christoph Schlueter
Peter Amann
Anders Nilsson

item.title: Spatial IMA1 regulation restricts root iron acquisition on MAMP perception
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06891-y

Microorganism-associated molecular patterns such as flagellin lead to suppression of root iron acquisition through localized degradation of the systemic iron-deficiency signalling peptide Iron Man 1 in Arabidopsis thaliana.
item.dc:title: Spatial IMA1 regulation restricts root iron acquisition on MAMP perception
item.dc:creator: Min Cao
Matthieu Pierre Platre
Huei-Hsuan Tsai
Ling Zhang
Tatsuya Nobori
Laia Armengot
Yintong Chen
Wenrong He
Lukas Brent
Nuria S. Coll
Joseph R. Ecker
Niko Geldner
Wolfgang Busch

item.title: Elevated genetic risk for multiple sclerosis emerged in steppe pastoralist populations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06618-z

Analysis of a large ancient genome dataset shows that genetic risk for multiple sclerosis rose in steppe pastoralists, providing insight into how genetic ancestry from the Neolithic and Bronze Age has shaped modern immune responses.
item.dc:title: Elevated genetic risk for multiple sclerosis emerged in steppe pastoralist populations
item.dc:creator: William Barrie
Yaoling Yang
Evan K. Irving-Pease
Kathrine E. Attfield

item.title: Nasopharyngeal lymphatic plexus is a hub for cerebrospinal fluid drainage
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06899-4

The nasopharyngeal lymphatic plexus is a major hub for cerebrospinal fluid outflow to deep cervical lymph nodes.
item.dc:title: Nasopharyngeal lymphatic plexus is a hub for cerebrospinal fluid drainage
item.dc:creator: Jin-Hui Yoon
Hokyung Jin
Hae Jin Kim
Seon Pyo Hong
Myung Jin Yang
Ji Hoon Ahn
Young-Chan Kim
Jincheol Seo
Yongjeon Lee
Donald M. McDonald
Michael J. Davis
Gou Young Koh

item.title: Self-citations in around a dozen countries are unusually high
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00090-z

Researchers behind the analysis think that policy incentives in these places are to blame.
item.dc:title: Self-citations in around a dozen countries are unusually high
item.dc:creator: Dalmeet Singh Chawla

item.title: Observing mammalian cerebellum development through an evolutionary lens
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03836-3

Tracking the gene-expression profiles of individual cerebellar cells during development in humans, mice and opossums revealed evolutionarily conserved as well as species-specific cellular and molecular features.
item.dc:title: Observing mammalian cerebellum development through an evolutionary lens

item.title: DNA sensing and repair systems unexpectedly team up against cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03994-4

DNA in the cytoplasm can be a sign of abnormalities such as viral infections or cancer. A protein with a role in DNA-damage response was unexpectedly found to activate defences against the threats indicated by cytoplasmic DNA.
item.dc:title: DNA sensing and repair systems unexpectedly team up against cancer
item.dc:creator: Silvia Monticelli
Petr Cejka

item.title: Drain ‘pipes’ behind the nose clear cerebrospinal fluid from the brain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03839-0

This study reveals a distinctive network of lymphatic vessels at the back of the nose that serves as a major hub for the outflow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) to deep cervical lymph nodes in the neck. These deep cervical lymphatics remain intact with ageing, and their pharmacological activation enhanced CSF drainage in mice.
item.dc:title: Drain ‘pipes’ behind the nose clear cerebrospinal fluid from the brain

item.title: Directly observing catalytic chemistry in the Haber–Bosch process
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03674-3

The Haber–Bosch process for making ammonia has been world-changing, but is highly energy-intensive owing to the high temperatures and pressures involved. A detailed understanding of the catalytic steps that occur in the basic reactions, and what limits them, opens the way to developing greener versions of the process.
item.dc:title: Directly observing catalytic chemistry in the Haber–Bosch process

item.title: Daily briefing: The earliest fossil evidence of photosynthesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00091-y

Photosynthetic structures in tiny fossils are 1.2 billion years older than previous finds. Plus, Neptune isn’t as blue as most people think and what happens when plagiarism is weaponized.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: The earliest fossil evidence of photosynthesis
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: A 2D route to 3D computer chips
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03992-6

Ultrathin materials have long been touted as a solution to the problems faced by the ever-growing semiconductor industry. Evidence that 3D chips can be built from 2D semiconductors suggests that the hype was justified.
item.dc:title: A 2D route to 3D computer chips
item.dc:creator: Tania Roy

item.title: How plants iron out the competing interests of growth and defence
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03995-3

Once a plant recognizes a pathogen, part of its defence strategy is to withhold iron. The mechanism involves suppression of root acquisition of iron by degrading a molecule that activates the iron-uptake pathway.
item.dc:title: How plants iron out the competing interests of growth and defence
item.dc:creator: Shanice S. Webster
Mary Lou Guerinot

item.title: MANNA
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00042-7

The taste of things to come.
item.dc:title: MANNA
item.dc:creator: S. R. Algernon

item.title: Deadly mismatch between nuclear and mitochondrial genes in swordtail fish hybrids
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03842-5

An analysis of the genomes of hybrids of distinct swordtail fish species uncovered a lethal incompatibility between certain combinations of nuclear and mitochondrial genes that encode subunits of complex I — a component of the mitochondrial respiratory chain. The evolutionary history of this incompatibility indicates that the genes involved were transferred between the species through hybridization in the past.
item.dc:title: Deadly mismatch between nuclear and mitochondrial genes in swordtail fish hybrids

item.title: Snow loss pinned to human-induced emissions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03993-5

Analysis of a large, varied data set reveals that snow cover in the Northern Hemisphere has undergone marked changes in the past four decades. Evidence that humans caused the shift suggests that snow loss will accelerate in the future.
item.dc:title: Snow loss pinned to human-induced emissions
item.dc:creator: Jouni Pulliainen

item.title: Spin supersolid with giant magnetocaloric effect promises a new route to extreme cooling
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04102-2

Supersolids are long-sought-after quantum materials with two seemingly contradictory features: a rigid solid structure and superfluidity. A triangular-lattice cobaltate material provides evidence for a quantum spin analogue of supersolidity, with an additional giant magnetocaloric effect — discoveries that pave the way for helium-free cooling to temperatures below 1 kelvin with frustrated quantum magnets.
item.dc:title: Spin supersolid with giant magnetocaloric effect promises a new route to extreme cooling

item.title: Why did the world’s biggest ape go extinct?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00033-8

The 300-kilogram primate couldn’t adapt when a changing environment forced a dietary shift.
item.dc:title: Why did the world’s biggest ape go extinct?
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: There are holes in Europe’s AI Act — and researchers can help to fill them
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00029-4

Scientists have been promised a front-row seat for the formulation of the EU’s proposed AI regulatory structures. They should seize this opportunity to bridge some big gaps.
item.dc:title: There are holes in Europe’s AI Act — and researchers can help to fill them

item.title: Prehistoric events might explain European multiple sclerosis risk
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03977-5

An exploration of more than 1,600 ancient Eurasian genomes suggests that genetic changes that increase autoimmune-disease risk in modern Europeans could have protected ancient Europeans from pathogens.
item.dc:title: Prehistoric events might explain European multiple sclerosis risk
item.dc:creator: Samira Asgari
Lionel A. Pousaz

item.title: First approval for controversial sea-bed mining worries scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00088-7

Researchers say the Norwegian government ignored warnings of potential ecosystem harm.
item.dc:title: First approval for controversial sea-bed mining worries scientists
item.dc:creator: Natasha Gilbert

item.title: Ancient DNA reveals origins of multiple sclerosis in Europe
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00024-9

A huge cache of ancient genomes spanning tens of thousands of years reveals the roots of traits in modern Europeans.
item.dc:title: Ancient DNA reveals origins of multiple sclerosis in Europe
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: AI could transform metal recycling globally
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00022-x

AI could transform metal recycling globally
item.dc:title: AI could transform metal recycling globally
item.dc:creator: Xu Tian
Joseph Sarkis

item.title: Can AI make genuine theoretical discoveries?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00020-z

Can AI make genuine theoretical discoveries?
item.dc:title: Can AI make genuine theoretical discoveries?
item.dc:creator: Yang-Hui He
Mikhail Burtsev

item.title: Stiff gel as squishable as a sponge takes its cue from cartilage
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00004-z

Polymers similar to those used in bulletproof vests are a key component of the water-rich ‘hydrospongel’.
item.dc:title: Stiff gel as squishable as a sponge takes its cue from cartilage

item.title: Climate policy must integrate blue energy with food security
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00023-w

Climate policy must integrate blue energy with food security
item.dc:title: Climate policy must integrate blue energy with food security
item.dc:creator: Yuyan Gong
Liuyue He
Guanqiong Ye
Jiangning Zeng

item.title: From the archive: the other Darwin, and illegitimate access to honey
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04000-7

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: the other Darwin, and illegitimate access to honey

item.title: Apply publication-charge waivers across hybrid journals, too
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00021-y

Apply publication-charge waivers across hybrid journals, too
item.dc:title: Apply publication-charge waivers across hybrid journals, too
item.dc:creator: Daniel Keirs

item.title: Why the immune response to a vaccine varies from person to person
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00005-y

A dormant immune system before receiving the BCG vaccine is tied to a greater innate immune response afterwards.
item.dc:title: Why the immune response to a vaccine varies from person to person

item.title: How CRISPR could yield the next blockbuster crop
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00015-w

Scientists are attempting to rapidly domesticate wild plant species by editing specific genes, but they face major technical challenges — and concerns about exploitation of Indigenous knowledge.
item.dc:title: How CRISPR could yield the next blockbuster crop
item.dc:creator: Michael Marshall

item.title: Daily briefing: What makes pee yellow
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00049-0

The enzyme that turns a red-orange precursor into urine’s yellow compound has finally been identified. Plus, the latest private Moon mission might be doomed and a baby’s heart-valve transplant has grown with its young recipient.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: What makes pee yellow
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: Why superintelligent AI won’t sneak up on us
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00084-x

Sudden jumps in large language models’ apparent intelligence are often a result of the way their performance is tested. Plus, a GPT-powered robot chemist designs reactions and what’s in store for AI in 2024.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: Why superintelligent AI won’t sneak up on us
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Breaking the menstruation taboo to make fieldwork more inclusive
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00044-5

We need to talk about periods when planning routine fieldwork trips, say ecologist Sarah E. Dalrymple and glaciologist Timothy P. Lane.
item.dc:title: Breaking the menstruation taboo to make fieldwork more inclusive
item.dc:creator: Sarah Dalrymple
Timothy Lane

item.title: How online misinformation exploits ‘information voids’ — and what to do about it
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00030-x

In 2024’s super election year, providers of online search engines and their users need to be especially aware of how online misinformation can seem all too credible.
item.dc:title: How online misinformation exploits ‘information voids’ — and what to do about it

item.title: Mission failure feared for private US Moon lander — what’s next?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00038-3

Astrobotic, the firm that launched the Peregrine spacecraft, says it will learn from any missteps and look ahead to its next attempt.
item.dc:title: Mission failure feared for private US Moon lander — what’s next?
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: In Brazil, one in two female researchers has faced sexual harassment
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00045-4

A survey by the Brazilian Academy of Sciences bolsters calls to tackle the problem.
item.dc:title: In Brazil, one in two female researchers has faced sexual harassment
item.dc:creator: Meghie Rodrigues

item.title: Life is short for baby monkeys amid the oil palms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00008-9

Young southern pig-tailed macaques, an endangered species, are less likely to reach their first birthday if they spend time on plantations.
item.dc:title: Life is short for baby monkeys amid the oil palms

item.title: Tasmanian devil die-off is shifting another predator’s genetics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00034-7

Devil population crashes caused by contagious tumours have knock-on effects elsewhere in the food chain.
item.dc:title: Tasmanian devil die-off is shifting another predator’s genetics
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: How I fuse Western science with Traditional Knowledge
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00018-7

Indigenous Canadian ecologist Jennifer Grenz abandons colonial restoration dogma to reshape land systems according to community needs.
item.dc:title: How I fuse Western science with Traditional Knowledge
item.dc:creator: Virginia Gewin

item.title: Ionized gas extends over 40 kpc in an odd radio circle host galaxy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06752-8

We find that the optical emission due to ionized gas that is characteristic of a shock extends 40 kpc in diameter across the host galaxy of an odd radio circle.
item.dc:title: Ionized gas extends over 40 kpc in an odd radio circle host galaxy
item.dc:creator: Alison L. Coil
Serena Perrotta
David S. N. Rupke
Cassandra Lochhaas
Christy A. Tremonti
Aleks Diamond-Stanic
Drummond Fielding
James E. Geach
Ryan C. Hickox
John Moustakas
Gregory H. Rudnick

Kelly E. Whalen

item.title: How we remember the dead by their digital afterlives
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00016-9

A broad-ranging analysis asks whether we can achieve a kind of immortality by documenting our lives and deaths online.
item.dc:title: How we remember the dead by their digital afterlives
item.dc:creator: Margaret Gibson

item.title: Private US Moon mission launches — will it open a new era for science?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04064-5

Astrobotic could be the first commercial firm to successfully deliver research equipment to the lunar surface, if it sticks the landing.
item.dc:title: Private US Moon mission launches — will it open a new era for science?
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Daily briefing: Where long COVID is understudied and ignored
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00040-9

A lack of data and recognition is hampering action on long COVID in many low-income countries. Plus, half of the world’s mining areas are undocumented and reindeer can chew while they snooze.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Where long COVID is understudied and ignored
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Boosting microbiome science worldwide could save millions of children’s lives
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00017-8

Studies of the microbes living on and in our bodies are conducted mainly in a few rich countries, squandering opportunities to improve the health of people globally.
item.dc:title: Boosting microbiome science worldwide could save millions of children’s lives
item.dc:creator: Hilary P. Browne
Najeeha Talat Iqbal
Majdi Osman
Caroline Tigoi
Trevor D. Lawley
